text:
Construction on New York's great cathedral to be resumed soon.

New photo of the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, on which construction is to be resumed soon. This photo shows the apse, or East end, with seven radiating chapels; and the crossing, with its temporary dome.

The nave, or staff of the cross, which this completed church will form, is the next part to be built. It is also planned to erect a great tower, 500 feet high, above the present, temporary dome.

March 10, 1924  Underwood and Underwood

Even in its unfinished condition the Cathedral represents an expenditure of more than $5,000,000 and when completed will have cost four times as much. There will be seats for 7,000 persons. Some of the seven chapels are as commodious as many churches. It is expected that the Cathedral will be completed within ten years.

Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th St.

text:
OLD WORLD GRANDEUR IN NEW WORLD CATHEDRALS. CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE.

New York--- the ambulatory of the Cathedral. This is a passage about twenty feet wide which runs completely around the choir and gives access to the seven chapels of tongues. At the left the photo shows the tomb of the founder of the Cathedral, Bishop Horatio Potter; sixth Bishop of New York. Its Position, immediately behind the altar is that traditionally reserved for the founder of a cathedral. It was designed by in the English Gothic style of the Fifteenth Century after studies of the tomb of Edward the Confessor, in Westminster Abbey. The photo was taken from the doorway of the Chapel of St. Martin of Tours. In the distance is the wrought iron screen before the chapel of Saint Columba and beyond that the screen before the chapel of St. Boniface is invisible.
Dec. 2, 1924

International Newsreel
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

text:
THE FRONT OF THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE With its twin towers, Rose window, and five entrances.
Feb. 1925
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

text:
INTERIOR OF THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE AS NOW IN USE.

This shows the choir and altar, and a portion of the crossing. The eight massive pillars around the altar are of Maine granite 54 feet high, each composed of only two pieces. Present plans call for replacing the semi-dome with a much higher structural roof. There would thus be another series of windows, 120 feet from the floor.

Interior of the Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, looking east toward the High Altar. The photograph shows the great pillars which stand about the Sanctuary.

Feb. 1925

The Review of Reviews.
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th Street

text:
Central Park: Harlem Mere, in the northeastern corner of the Park; the view is north from Mount St. Vincent. The southern end of Lenox Avenue is behind the boathouse. The older part of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Morningside Heights, is shown in the left background.

About 1925.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Harlem Mere.

text:
THE VAST NAVE OF THE CATHEDRAL OF SAINT JOHN THE DIVINE NOW UNDER CONSTRUCTION.

It seems only a short time since the cornerstone of the Cathedral nave was set in place with due ceremonies. The vast structure is rising rapidly, and now adds one more to the edifices that make Morningside Heights and educational and religious center typifying the higher interests of the metropolis.
May 1926
from the Review of Reviews
title: Manhattan: Amsterdam Avenue - Cathedral Parkway - 113th St.

text:
IDENTIFICATION: Aerial view of Morningside Heights, Manhattan, showing Cathedral of St. John the Divine, etc.
DATE: 1 Sept. 1926
PHOTOGRAPHER: Fairchild Aerial Surveys, Inc.
270 W. 38, NYC
